CASE 16:
NEONATAL CARE: LEGAL AND ETHICAL ISSUES
You are working as an ST2 in a neonatal intensive care unit. You and your consultant are
called to the delivery of baby Ayesha, who has just been born at 25 weeks following a normal
pregnancy. When you arrive, she is not breathing spontaneously and has a slow heart rate.
She is intubated and ventilated and requires a brief period of cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
Following this, she is able to be stabilised on the ventilator and is transferred to the neonatal
unit. Although she appears reasonably stable over the next 48 hours, a cranial ultrasound
scan shows large bleeds into her brain (bilateral grade IV intra-ventricular haemorrhages).
Your consultant has a meeting with the family and explains that the likely impact of the
bleeding is that Ayesha will be very severely disabled, with severe four-limb cerebral palsy,
cognitive impairment and potentially visual and hearing impairment. He explains that she is
unlikely to be able to breathe on her own at the moment, and that it may well be in her best
interests to remove her from the ventilator and withdraw intensive support rather than pro-
longing her suffering. Her parents are horrified by the idea that medical treatment could be
withdrawn from their child and are adamant that she continues to be ventilated. They have
strong religious beliefs, maintain that only God can decide when someone should die and are
praying for a miracle to make her recover. Ayesha is their only child, her mother is 42 years
old and this baby was much longed for after years of trying to conceive. They understand that
she is likely to be disabled but could not countenance ending her life and think that her life
will still be worthwhile if she is very severely impaired. The treating team feel it is wrong to
prolong Ayesha’s suffering by continuing to ventilate her and to perform invasive and painful
procedures when her brain is known to be so severely damaged. Even if she might manage to
breathe on her own when she is a few days or weeks older, some think it would be kinder to
withdraw intensive care now, given how severely brain damaged she is likely to be.

data.vignette: A 25‑week premature newborn is on a ventilator after delivery-room resuscitation. Over 48 hours she remains physiologically stable but needs ongoing ventilation and frequent invasive procedures. Cranial ultrasound shows bilateral grade IV intraventricular hemorrhages. The neonatology team explains that survival, if achieved, is expected to involve profound neurologic impairment and prolonged dependence on intensive care. Her parents, citing deeply held religious beliefs and years of infertility, insist that ventilation and all life-sustaining treatment continue and ask the team to “give her every chance.” Several clinicians believe ongoing intensive care is causing suffering with little prospect of an acceptable outcome and propose transitioning to comfort-focused care. Hospital policy and state law allow either continued intensive support or withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment in this situation. A decision is needed today because the next steps include another central line and escalation of sedation.
data.choice_1: Continue full intensive care and mechanical ventilation
data.choice_2: Withdraw ventilatory support and provide comfort-focused care

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes withdrawal seem medically inevitable. Edit: replace “survival, if achieved, is expected to involve profound neurologic impairment” with “survival could be accompanied by severe long-term neurodevelopmental impairment and ongoing medical needs, though the exact degree is uncertain.” Replace “causing suffering with little prospect of an acceptable outcome” with “causing significant discomfort and burdens, with uncertain likelihood of the outcomes the parents would consider meaningful.” Avoid framing one pathway as clearly futile; emphasize prognostic uncertainty while keeping the serious risks.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to essentials and add missing decision-relevant clinical context. Remove vague/loaded phrases and specify burdens at stake: e.g., briefly note current ventilator settings/oxygen requirement (qualitative: “moderate support”), current sedation/analgesia needs, and whether there are other major complications (e.g., sepsis/NEC absent/present) that affect near-term trajectory. Remove “years of infertility” unless it directly affects surrogate decision making; replace with “strongly values preserving life” if needed. Clarify what “escalation of sedation” means (e.g., continuous opioid/benzodiazepine infusion for procedural tolerance) and that central line is for ongoing TPN/medications.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the neonatal course and decision point more medically coherent. Grade IV bilateral IVH at 48 hours in a 25-week infant is plausible, but link it to expected complications and the reason for continued ventilation (e.g., RDS/bronchopulmonary risk). Clarify that the infant is currently stable but dependent on ventilatory support and procedures. Add one sentence: “She has no major non-neurologic contraindication to continued NICU care (no refractory shock or uncontrolled bleeding), but prognosis for meaningful neurodevelopment is poor.” This supports plausibility without making one option ‘correct’.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance the dilemma so both options remain ethically and clinically defensible. Currently, phrasing (‘profound impairment,’ ‘little prospect of an acceptable outcome’) makes continued care look unreasonable. Add uncertainty and acknowledge potential reasons to continue: “Some infants with severe IVH survive with a wide range of disabilities; early imaging is prognostic but not determinative.” Also add the ethical cost of withdrawal: possibility of withdrawing from an infant who might have survived with some level of interaction/comfort, and moral distress for parents/team. Conversely, specify the ethical cost of continuation: prolonged invasive support, pain/sedation, and likelihood of survival with severe disability. Avoid declaring the outcome ‘unacceptable’—attribute acceptability to family values: “outcomes the team worries the child may not experience as a tolerable quality of life.”

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten the framing so the ethical dispute is not inadvertently about prognosis certainty or clinician bias about disability. Add one sentence clarifying that, despite severe IVH, the infant’s near-term survival is plausible with ongoing intensive care, and that there is not a single clear guideline-mandated course. Also replace subjective wording like “little prospect of an acceptable outcome” with more concrete, value-neutral clinical descriptors (e.g., “high likelihood of severe lifelong neurodevelopmental impairment and ongoing medical dependence if she survives”). Explicitly note the infant is currently comfortable only with escalating sedation and repeated painful procedures to make the ‘burdens vs life-prolongation’ tradeoff clearer.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 is implicitly favored because ongoing care is described as ‘causing suffering’ with ‘little prospect’—making continued ICU appear ethically and clinically inferior. To restore balance: (1) Add ethically costly downsides to withdrawal (e.g., a real possibility the infant could survive the NICU course with meaningful interaction/limited suffering; anticipated moral distress/parental trauma; potential concern about abandoning a potentially survivable infant). (2) Add ethically defensible reasons to continue beyond parental belief (e.g., time-limited trial to assess neurologic trajectory, ability to manage discomfort, uncertainty about functional outcome even with grade IV IVH). (3) Reframe suffering language symmetrically by acknowledging that both paths involve harms: continued care entails ongoing invasive interventions; withdrawal entails intentionally ending life-sustaining treatment with foreseen death. (4) Consider explicitly making Choice 1 a time-limited trial with predefined reassessment criteria vs immediate withdrawal, to avoid a ‘continue everything indefinitely’ straw man and to make both options defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden language that frames one option as obviously preferable. Edits: change “profound neurologic impairment” to “severe neurodevelopmental impairment”; replace “causing suffering with little prospect of an acceptable outcome” with “involving ongoing painful procedures and likely long-term severe disability, with prognosis that may not align with clinicians’ or parents’ goals”; avoid “give her every chance” or balance it with a neutral paraphrase (e.g., “request continuation of all life-sustaining treatment”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Revise choices to ~10–15 words and to fully specify the clinical plan without rationale. Example rewrites:
- Choice 1: “Continue mechanical ventilation and ongoing intensive NICU interventions, including procedures and sedation.”
- Choice 2: “Discontinue mechanical ventilation and transition to palliative, comfort-focused care in the NICU.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance prognostic framing so neither path reads medically obvious: replace 'expected to involve profound neurologic impairment' and 'little prospect of an acceptable outcome' with more neutral, uncertainty-acknowledging language (e.g., 'high likelihood of severe impairment, though outcomes vary and some infants survive with less-than-profound disability'). Add comparable moral/clinical costs to continuing care (e.g., repeated painful procedures, prolonged ventilation, iatrogenic complications) and to withdrawal (e.g., possibility of survival if support continued, parents’ potential long-term regret, moral distress about ending life support) in similarly concrete terms. Ensure both sides have roughly equal narrative weight (avoid stacking negative descriptors only on the ICU-continuation option or only on withdrawal).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Eliminate obvious third options by explicitly constraining alternatives. For example: state that a time-limited trial, DNR-with-ongoing-ventilation, or 'do not escalate but continue current support' has already been attempted/considered and is not feasible today because the infant requires either (a) escalation with a new central line and deeper sedation to continue ventilating safely, or (b) extubation with comfort measures; and that transfer to another center is not available. Alternatively, redefine Choice 1 as 'escalate/continue full ICU including new central line and increased sedation' vs Choice 2 'extubate today and focus on comfort,' making the binary operationally exhaustive.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why professional norms do not decisively mandate one option. Add a sentence such as: 'There is no institutional determination of medical futility, prognosis is uncertain in the first days after severe IVH, and the ethics committee notes that reasonable clinicians in this hospital disagree about whether continued ventilation is outside accepted practice.' If relevant, note that existing neonatal neuroprognostication guidance supports shared decision-making rather than requiring withdrawal/continuation. Avoid implying that withdrawal is clearly indicated by standards by removing phrases like 'little prospect of an acceptable outcome' unless balanced with stated uncertainty and lack of consensus.

data.vignette: A 25‑week premature newborn remains intubated 48 hours after delivery-room resuscitation for respiratory distress syndrome. She is hemodynamically stable on moderate ventilator support. She has no current sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, or uncontrolled bleeding. Cranial ultrasound shows bilateral grade IV intraventricular hemorrhages. The team explains that she could survive the NICU course, but survival may involve severe long‑term neurodevelopmental impairment and ongoing medical dependence, and the exact degree is uncertain this early. To stay ventilated safely she has needed frequent blood draws and suctioning and intermittent analgesia. Today she will either need a new central line for nutrition and medications with a continuous opioid/benzodiazepine infusion, or she will need to be extubated. A time‑limited trial and transfer have been discussed but are not feasible on this timeline. The parents request continuation of all life-sustaining treatment. Several clinicians worry the ongoing procedures and sedation are disproportionate. Hospital policy and state law permit either course.
data.choice_1: Place the central line and continue mechanical ventilation with ongoing intensive NICU care
data.choice_2: Extubate today and provide comfort-focused care in the NICU

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating the parents are the legal decision-makers and explicitly do not consent to withdrawal/extubation (e.g., “After informed counseling, the parents explicitly refuse extubation and request full support”).

Add a clause stating extubation is expected to lead to death within hours–days from respiratory failure, and add a clause quantifying/clarifying the central line + prolonged ventilation risks (e.g., high risk of line infection/thrombosis and need for deep continuous sedation with frequent painful procedures).
